title: 111_hr3518
content: The Act is titled the "Waterfront Brownfields Revitalization Act" and includes a grant for waterfront brownfields. Section 104(k) of the Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act of 1980 is amended to establish a program for grants to eligible entities or nonprofit organizations for waterfront brownfields revitalization. Grants can be used for reuse planning, site characterization, and assessment. The amendment to Section 104(k) of the Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act of 1980 establishes a program for grants for waterfront brownfields revitalization. Grants can be used for activities related to water quality improvements, low impact development approaches, green infrastructure, sediment management, and flood damage prevention at brownfields sites adjacent to bodies of water. The amendment to Section 104(k) of the Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act of 1980 authorizes grants up to $500,000 for waterfront brownfields revitalization. Additionally, $220,000,000 is authorized for fiscal years 2010 through 2014 for this purpose. The amendment authorizes up to $55,000,000 or 25 percent of the available amount for site characterization, assessment, and remediation of facilities. Additionally, funds are authorized for waterfront brownfields revitalization grants. SEC. 3. TASK FORCE. The Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency will establish a task force on waterfront brownfields revitalization, with members including experts from various organizations and government agencies. The Administrator will establish a task force on waterfront brownfields revitalization, with members including experts from various organizations and government agencies. The task force will identify funding resources, barriers, and coordination methods for waterfront brownfields revitalization. A report detailing the findings must be submitted to Congress within 3 years of the Act's enactment. The annual report must be submitted to Congress within 3 years of the Act's enactment. The Administrator of the EPA must submit an annual report to Congress on the brownfield site grant program. Committees in the House of Representatives must hold hearings on the report each year. The House of Representatives has the power to make rules that supersede any other House rule if they are inconsistent. The House also has the constitutional right to change these rules relating to House procedures at any time.
